definition:
recollection, memory                                      
             
             keep that in mind

the element or complex (see complex entry 1 sense 1) of elements in an individual that feels, perceives, thinks, wills, and especially reasons                                      
             
             Keep your mind active as you grow older.
the conscious mental events and capabilities in an organism
the organized conscious and unconscious adaptive mental activity of an organism

intention, desire                                      
             
             I changed my mind

the normal or healthy condition of the mental faculties                                      
             
             Who in their right mind would try such a stunt?

opinion, view                                      
             
             was urged to speak his mind

disposition, mood                                      
             
             He's in a bad state of mind.

a person or group embodying mental qualities                                      
             
             the public mind

intellectual ability                                      
             
             the works of men of mind
god sense 1b
a conscious substratum or factor in the universe

attention                                      
             
             pay him no mind
remind
remember
to attend to closely
to become aware of : notice

to regard with attention : consider important                                      
                
                  —often used in the imperative with following you for emphasis          I'm not against inspiration, mind you; I simply refuse to sit and stare at a blank page waiting for it— Dennis Whitcomb
intend, purpose
to give heed to attentively in order to obey
to follow the orders or instructions of
to be concerned about

dislike                                      
             
             I don't mind going

to be careful : see                                      
             
             mind you finish it

to be cautious about                                      
             
             mind the broken rung
to give protective care to : tend
to be attentive or wary
to become concerned : care
to pay obedient heed or attention
the part of a person that thinks, reasons, feels, and remembers
—used to describe the way a person thinks or the intelligence of a person
a very intelligent person
to be bothered by (something) : to object to or dislike (something)
to care about or worry about (something or someone)
—used to make a polite request
the part of a person that thinks, reasons, feels, understands, and remembers

memory sense 1                                      
             
             Keep my advice in mind.

intention sense 1                                      
             
             I changed my mind.

a person's view or opinion about something                                      
             
             Speak your mind.

to pay attention to                                      
             
             Mind what you're doing.

obey sense 1                                      
             
             Be sure to mind the teacher.

to be bothered by                                      
                   
             "Don't mind the boys," Abigail whispered. "They tease."

to object to : dislike                                      
             
             I don't mind the cold.

to take charge of                                      
             
             Please mind the children.

to be careful about                                      
             
             You should mind what you say.
the element or complex of elements in an individual that feels, perceives, thinks, wills, and especially reasons
in: keep that in mind
time out of mind
Keep your mind active as you grow older.
I changed my mind
Who in their right mind would try such a stunt?
was urged to speak his mind
He's in a bad state of mind.
the public mind
the works of men of mind
pay him no mind
I'm not against inspiration, mind you; I simply refuse to sit and stare at a blank page waiting for it
I don't mind going
mind you finish it
mind the broken rung
He read great literature to develop his mind.
It's important to keep your mind active as you grow older.
He went for a walk to help clear his mind.
the mysteries of the human mind
My mind is always open to new ideas.
You can't argue with him. His mind is closed.
I can't concentrate: my mind is always wandering and I can't keep it focused on anything.
The smell of pine sends my mind back to childhood.
The sound of her voice jerked my mind back to the present.
My mind tells me it can't work, but my heart tells me I want to try it.
It was raining, but I didn't mind.
I don't mind very much what happens.
“Why is he so angry?” “Oh, don't mind him. He's always complaining about something.”
Keep my advice in mind.
I changed my mind.
Speak your mind.
Mind what you're doing.
Be sure to mind the teacher.
"Don't mind the boys," Abigail whispered. "They tease."
I don't mind the cold.
Please mind the children.
You should mind what you say.

definition: the part of you that thinks, knows, remembers, and feels things
your attention or thoughts
your usual way of thinking
your intelligence and ability to understand things
someone who is very intelligent
to understand something difficult
in: His mind was full of the things he had seen that day.
I need a walk to clear my mind.
in someone’s mind: You never know what’s going on in her mind.
Can you say that again? My mind was on something else.
keep your mind on something: I can’t keep my mind on work when it’s so sunny outside.
Ellen’s husband has a very suspicious mind.
a brilliant/keen mind
Her youngest child has a very enquiring mind  (=is very interested in things and always asking questions).
My grandmother’s mind is failing.
He is one of the finest minds in physics today.
at the back of your mind
be/go out of your mind
be in two minds (about something)
be of like mind
be of one/be of the same mind (about)
be of sound mind
bring/call someone/something to mind
change your/someone’s mind (about something)
come/spring to mind
get someone/something out of your mind
great minds think alike
have a good mind to do something/have half a mind to do something
have someone/something in mind
have (it) in mind to do something
have a mind of its own
have a mind of your own
have/keep an open mind
in your mind’s eye
it’s all in your mind
keep something in mind
keep someone in mind (for something)
the last thing on your mind
a load/weight off someone’s mind
lose your mind
make up your mind
mind blown
someone’s mind is/goes blank
mind over matter
on your mind
put someone in mind of
put someone/something out of your mind
put/set someone’s mind at ease/at rest
put/set/turn your mind to something
read someone’s mind
set your mind on doing something
state of mind
take your mind off something
to my mind
with someone/something in mind

definition: the part of a person that makes it possible for him or her to think, feel emotions, and understand things:
a very intelligent person:
If a problem is all in the mind, it does not exist and is only imagined:
to remember a piece of information when you are making a decision or thinking about a matter:
to think repeatedly about an event that has happened:
(used in questions and negatives) to be annoyed or worried by something:
said to someone when you feel annoyed with that person for what they have just done or said:
to be careful of, or give attention to something:
used to tell someone to move or be careful, or to warn someone of danger:
said when you say goodbye to someone, meaning "take care"
to take care of someone or something:
to listen to and obey someone:
in: Her mind was full of what had happened the night before, and she just wasn't concentrating.
Of course I'm telling the truth - you have such a suspicious mind!
I just said the first thing that came into my mind.
I'm not quite clear in my mind about what I'm doing.
She was one of the most brilliant minds of the last century.
His doctor tried to convince him that he wasn't really ill and that it was all in his mind.
Bearing in mind how young she is, I thought she did really well.
Of course, repair work is expensive and you have to keep that in mind.
She kept going over the accident again and again in her mind, wishing that she could somehow have prevented it.
Do you think he'd mind if I borrowed his book?
I don't mind having a dog in the house so long as it's clean.
I wouldn't mind (= I would like) something to eat, if that's OK.
Would you mind turning (= please turn) your radio down a little please?
Do you mind if I (= may I) put the TV on?
Do you mind me smoking?
I don't mind what you wear so long as it's not that awful pink shirt.
I'd rather stay in tonight, if you don't mind.
"Would you like tea or coffee?" "I don't mind - either."
Do you mind? That's my seat you're sitting on!
Mind that box - the bottom isn't very strong.
Mind (that) you don't bang your head on the shelf when you stand up.
Mind (= make certain that) you take enough money with you.
Mind your language (= don't use swear words), young lady!
Mind out! We're coming through with the stretcher.
"Hey, mind!" he said when she trod on his foot.
Mind out for falling rocks on this part of the trail.
She asked me if I'd mind the children for an hour while she went shopping.
Could you mind my bag for a moment while I go to the toilet?
Mind your grandma!
This dog won't mind.

translated_as@ru: сходить с ума от тревоги/горя и т. д.
не могли бы вы …? вы не возражаете ...?

translated_as@fr: les pensées qui tournoyaient dans son esprit
Il n’y avait aucun doute dans mon esprit qu’elle disait la vérité.
J’ai eu beaucoup de choses à l’esprit récemment.
Je me suis assis pour commencer à écrire et j’ai vraiment eu un trou.
l’un des grands esprits de notre génération
J’allais acheter le rouge mais j’ai changé d’avis.
Cela m’a traversé l’esprit qu’elle espérait que j’échouerais.
dire sa façon de penser à qqn
Je vais lui dire ma façon de penser si elle essaie cela à nouveau.
un jeune homme qui a sa façon de penser
Ce n’est pas le genre de musique que nous avions en tête.
je savais que je devrais lui parler de cela.
Je suis ici pour vous aider
gardez cela à l’esprit si vous avez des problèmes.
Je n’arrive pas à me décider
Essayez de garder l’esprit ouvert tandis que vous prenez votre décision.
ça m’est complétement sorti de l’esprit.
Elle est allée à la réception sans moi mais ça ne me dérange pas.
Est-ce que cela t’ennuie d’être le dernier ?
Cela ne dérangera pas papa si nous empruntons la voiture.
Fais attention au trou dans la route.
Est-ce que cela t’/vous ennuie/dérange si … ?
Est-ce que cela vous ennuie si je jette un coup d’œil à votre journal ?
Je prendrais bien un petit quelque chose à manger.
occupe-toi/occupez-vous de ce qui te/vous regarde
J’aimerais que les gens s’occupent de ce qui les regarde.
Cela vous ennuierait/dérangerait-il de me donner un coup de main pour ceci ?

definition: Mind is a word frequently used in Scotland meaning:memory, remembrance, recollection.In numerous phrases with verbs, constituting the equivalents of verbs of remembering, recalling or reminding.

Marginalized Orientations, Gender identities, And Intersex. it’s meant to be an all inclusive umbrella term for asexuals, homosexuals, multisexuals, trans people, and intersex people. Alternative to LGBTQIAP+
Alternative to MOGII, easier to pronounce.
majndA part of existence that philosophers and scientists just can't seem to "wrap their minds around", albeit it has been at the center of philosophical and scientific discourse for centuries.

Throughout modern times the word 'mind' has been added to the end of all sentences spoke in the Gloucester (UK) area.  It can indicate a question, acceptance, frustration, to big up a conquest or anything you so choose!
A place to keep your things.
Something that a pimp will take away from a weak woman.
Mentally independent nervous dispositions
